subject: Re: [junit] Is it Time for JUnit 5
msgSnippet: Not to stem the tide, but if there are individual features you d like to see in any future version of JUnit, 4.x _or_ 5.x, the best place is the github issues
messageBody:
Not to stem the tide, but if there are individual features you'd like to
see in any future version of JUnit, 4.x _or_ 5.x, the best place is the
github issues repo at https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues. Once
you've logged the feature request there, feel free to circulate it in a new
thread on this list to drive discussion. It may be that a feature you
think requires a full version bump in JUnit 5 can be easily layered on top
of current JUnit 4 features, once looked at in the right way.

Oh, and message received on donuts. :-)

David


On Wed, Dec 19, 2012 at 6:55 PM, jeevan <g1reddych@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> It would be good if jUnit produces results while running test cases from
> eclipse IDE.
>
> Is there any option to run selective test cases, lets says one Java Class
> file contains 10 test cases.
> Can i run two test cases out of 10 instead of creating one Java class file
> one test case (1 to 1)
> Like:
> public class SearchEnginesTest{
>
> @BeforeTest
> public void setUp() throws Exception{
> //Driver setup
> }
> @Test
> public void yahooTest() throws Exception{
> _driver.get("http://www.yahoo.com");
> Thread.sleep(2000);
> _driver.findElement(By.id("p_13838465-p")).sendKeys("Junit");
> }
>
> @Test
> public void googleTest() throws Exception{
> _driver.get("http://www.google.com");
> Thread.sleep(2000);
> _driver.findElement(By.name("q")).sendKeys("Junit");
> }
> .....
> list goes till 10.
> }
>
> Thanks,
> Jeevan.
>
> On Wed, Dec 19, 2012 at 8:32 AM, Mirko Friedenhagen <
> mfriedenhagen@...
> > wrote:
>
> > **
>
> >
> >
> > Hello Esko,
> >
> > junit compatibilty would probably allow to use maven's surefire plugin,
> so
> > this would be really nice.
> >
> > Regards Mirko
> > --
> > Sent from my mobile
> >
> > On Dec 19, 2012 11:38 AM, "Esko Luontola" <esko.luontola@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > > Neale Upstone wrote on 19.12.2012 10:48:
> > > > Certainly ensuring a smooth transition is important, given the number
> > of
> > > > place JUnit is consumed.
> > >
> > > +1
> > >
> > > That's why JUnit backward compatibility is very high on Jumi's TODO
> > > list, right after automatic test discovery. It's probable that I'll get
> > > to implement it during this winter holiday.
> > >
> > > Jumi's expressiveness is a superset of the JUnit test runner, so it
> > > should work out quite nicely. I think Jumi's API is more fail-fast than
> > > JUnit's test runner API, so some misbehaving custom JUnit runners might
> > > fail to run, but I'm expecting those to be in the minority. Vanilla
> > > JUnit 3 + 4 compatibility is most important.
> > >
> > > --
> > > Esko Luontola
> > > www.orfjackal.net
